Description: Each presentation in this session will describe a distinct clinical vaccine research effort whose long-term goal is to prevent cancer.  One vaccine targets an infectious etiology, while the other two do not.  The HPV vaccine is directed against several HPV types whose long-term infection causes cervical cancer, oropharyngeal cancer, and several other types of cancer.  The experimental Lynch syndrome vaccine targets a range of mutations that frequently develop in cancers in patients with this syndrome, a familial predisposition to develop colorectal, endometrial, and other types of cancer because of defective DNA mismatch repair.  The experimental K-RAS vaccine is composed of the most common K-RAS mutations that occur in pancreatic adenocarcinomas, the vast majority of which harbor mutant K-RAS

Title: Immunoprevention and Clinical Trials
